bibl.title: Sacred Stories of the Sweet Grass Cree
bibl.series: National Museum of Canada, Bulletin no. 60, Anthropological Series, no. 11

encodingdesc.p: This electronic document is oriented more toward representing those features that seem most likely to be relevant for grammatical analyses, rather than toward faithfully representing all the information available in the book.

list.item: 2014 06 10; KR; UTF-8, paragraph and sentence numbering, smart-quotes in English translations

p.seg: pêyak ês ôma ôtênaw êh-misâk , êh-mâh-mêtawêcik , êh-môtocik . The story goes that there was this big town where they always had contests and ate each other.
kîtahtawê pêyak awa iskwêw pakwâtam , êh-kitimâkêyimât osîmisah . Then at one time a certain woman took a dislike to this, because she loved her little brother.
nka-sipwêhtahâw ; ta-kakwê-ohpikiw , itêyihtam . “I shall take him away from here; I shall try to have him grow up,” she thought.
êh-tipiskâyik , sipwêhtêw , êh-tapasît . In the night she went away, fleeing.

mâskôc , - nôhtâwiy nikâwiy êh-nipahihcik , êkwah nipêyakon nisîmis , - asici mâskôc mêtawêhkih , êkwah nika-nipahikawin , itêyihtam ; êyakô ohci k-ô-sipwêhtêt . “Perhaps since my father and my mother have been killed, I am now alone with my little brother perhaps, if there is another mass contest, I now shall be killed,” she thought; that is why she went away.
nistwâw êh-nipât , êkotê miywâsiniyiw askiy , misiwê ê-sakâyik . After two nights journeying, she was at a place where the land was good, with woods everywhere.

âh , mâskôc ôta nam âwiyak nik-ôtihtik , itêyihtam ;
êkosi tit-ôhpikiw nisîmis , itêyihtam . “Oh, perhaps here no one will come upon me,” she thought; “In this way my little brother will grow up,” she thought.
tâpwê êkotah osîhtâw wîkih . So there she set up her dwelling.
kiyipa kîsihtâw wîki . She quickly built her lodge.

êkwah osîhtâw astis ohci tâpakwâna , ê-wîh-kakwê-nipahât wâposwa ,
êkotôwahk piko nik-ôh-pimâtisinân nisîmis , êh-itêyihtah . Then she made snares of sinew, meaning to try to kill rabbits, thinking, “Only from these shall my little brother and I be able to get our sustenance.”
tâpwê tâpakwêw . So she set her snares.
êkwah mihtah mistahih âwatâw . Then she gathered a great amount of firewood.
êkw êh-tipiskâyik , ê-kîh-nipâcik , êh-wâpahk , nâtam otâpakwânah . Then, when night had come and they had slept, in the morning she went to look at her snares.
nîso nipahêw wâposwah . She had killed two rabbits.
hây hây ! êkwah nisîmis kê-mîcisot ! itwêw , êh-kîwêhtahât . “Good! Now my little brother will eat!” she said, as she took them home.
tâpwê miywêyihtam awa nâpêsis , êh-pêsîmiht wâposwah . The little boy was glad when the rabbits were brought.
êkwah kîsiswêw aw îskwêw , êy-asamât osîmisah . Then the woman cooked them and gave her little brother to eat.
ê-kîsi-mîcisot , kotakah mîna osîhtâw , âsa mîna êh-ntawi-tâpakwêt ; When she too had eaten, she made some more snares and went again to lay then;
êkoyihohk mâna kâh-kîwêcih , êh-atoskâtahk mihtah , itah êh-ay-ayât . and then, whenever she went home, she tended to the firewood, and stayed there.
piyisk misikitiyiwa osîma , êkwah êy-osîhtât acosisah , ê-kiskinôhamawât ta-pmotahkwêyit osîmisah . In time her brother grew big, and then she made arrows and taught him to shoot.
tâpwê kaskihtâw ê-pimotahkwêt awa nâpêsis . So the boy learned to shoot.
mâskôc kîkway wêh-nipahtâcih oskinîkicih , êh-itêyimât , k-ôh-kiskinôhamawât . Perhaps he will kill something when he comes to adolescence,” was why she taught him.

wiya tahto-kîsikâw êh-nipahât wâposwah , êyako piko êh-atoskêt , êkwah awa nâpêsis pisisik êh-mêtawêt pîhcâyihk , âskaw wayawîtimihk , awa piko iskwêw êh-atoskêt , mitoni kitimâkêyimêw osîmisa , itah ê-wiy-ôhpikihât . As she killed rabbits every day, she was the only one of them to work; as the boy was always playing in the lodge, or sometimes out of doors, and only the woman worked, she was very good to her little brother, there where she was trying to raise him.

kîtahtawê êkwah ê-misikitiyit osîma , osîhtâw otayôwinisiyiwa , wîki êh-pîkosahk , êyakô ohci oskotâkayiw êw-osîhtât , mîna otâsiyiwa . Then, presently, when her brother grew big, she made clothes for him, cutting pieces from the tent, from which she made him a coat and breeches.
êkwah wêskwâhtêmihk ohtapiw awa , êh-at-ôskinîkit ; And he sat in the place opposite the door, as he came to the age approaching manhood;
êkwah pêyakwanohk apiw awa , êh-at-oskinîkit . he stayed always right there, as he came to adolescence.

namoya êkwa papâmohtêw wayawîtimihk , nayêstaw êh-mîcisot , wâposwah piko êh-môwâcik omisah . He did not go about now out of doors; he did little more than eat his meals, and rabbits were all they had to eat, he and his sister.
nama wîhkâc kitotitôwak . They never spoke to each other.
piyisk oskinîkiw . At last he was a young man.

kîtahtawê otinam omôhkomân , ê-ntawi-kîskikahahk misâskwatwah , êkwah ahcâpiyah , êh-pîhtokatât , ê-wîh-osîhtât , êh-môhkotahk , ôhi mîna ahcâpiyah , acosisah ê-wîh-osîhtât . Then at one time he took his knife and went to cut some saskatoon sticks, and wood for a bow, and brought them inside the lodge to work at them, whittling them, and the bow as well, to make arrows.
êkwah namoya tâpwê kîh-nipahêw aw îskwêw wâposwah . And then the woman was no longer well able to kill rabbits.
êkwah nôhtêhkatêwak . Then they hungered.
pakwâtam aw îskwêw êh-nôhtêhkatêcik , osâm pêyakwanohk êh-apiyit osîma . The woman was grieved that they should hunger because her brother always stayed right there.

êkwah awa oskinîkiw k-ôsîhtât ôhi misâskwatwah , otinam cîkahikan , ê-ntawi-wanêhikêt mistikwah ohci , mistiko-wanêhikan . When the youth had prepared those saskatoon sticks, he took an ax and went to set a trap of boughs.
nîso osîhtâw . He made two of them.
êkosi êh-kîwêt , pêyak piko nipahêyiwa ômisah wâposwah . Then when he came home, his sister had killed but one rabbit.
pôti êh-wâpahk , ê-ntawâpahtahk owanihikanah , nipahêw kîhîwa , êkwah ôhôwa ; êkosi nîso . In the morning, when he went to look at his traps, he had killed an eagle and an owl; one in each trap.
êwakoni mîkwanah ohci osîhtâw wîpisisah . He made his arrows with those feathers.
êh-kîsihtât , êkwah omisah astis miyik , êy-osihtât , ahcâpîhk êh-tahkopitahk . When he had finished them, his sister gave him a sinew, which he prepared and fixed on his bow.

êkwah mîna êh-ntawâpahtahk owanêhikanah , tasôhêw nikikwah êkwah ocêkah , êkwah ocêkiwayânah ê-wîh-opîhtatwânit , nikikwa ê-wîh-otastotinit , nikikwayânah . The next time he went to look at his traps, he had trapped an otter and a fisher; and now he meant to make a quiver of the fisherskin, and of the otter a hat, of the otterskin.
êkwah ôhi kihîwa , oskan ôtah omatôwahk , otihcimanikanis otinam , kicohcikanis êh-osîhtât . And from the eagle he took the bone here, like this, from the upper part of the wing, and made a flute.
êh-kîs-ôsîhtât , otinamiyiwa omisah kâwiyah , ê-wîh-kikamohâyit kicohcikanisihk . When he had made it, his sister took some porcupine-quills to attach to the little flute.
êh-kîsihtâyit , akotâw . When she had finished it, he hung it up.

êkosi miywêyihtam aw îskwêw ,
êkwah kêkway ta-nipahtâw nisîm ! êh-itêyihtahk . Then the woman was glad, thinking, “Now my brother will kill something!”
pôtih nama wiya wîh-mâciyiwa osîma , pêyakwanohk êh-apiyit . But she found that her brother would not hunt, and did not stir from the spot.
âskaw nama kêkway nipahtâw wâposwah aw îskwêw . Often enough the woman did not kill any rabbits.
êkosi nama kêkway mîciwak . Then they had nothing to eat.

pakwâtam aw îskwêw êkâ ê-wîh-mâciyit osîma ; êkâ kêkway êh-asamât osîma , êyak ôhci k-ôh-pakwâtahk . She was grieved that her brother did not care to hunt; because she had nothing to give her brother to eat, was why she disliked it.
mîna êh-wâpahk , êh-nâtahk otâpakwâna , nama kêkway nipahtâw . The next morning, when she went to her snares, she had not killed anything.

êkwah êy-oskinîkit , wiyaskoc êtokê kêkway ta-nipahtâw , ta-mîciyâhk , nitêyihtêh , êkâ k-êspayik , itwêw aw îskwêw , êh-otinahk mihtah , ê-wîh-pônahk . “Now that he is a young man, he in his turn ought to kill something for us to eat; so I thought, at least, but it has not turned out that way,” said the woman, as she took up some faggots to put on the fire.
nka-pêhtâk nisîm , êh-itêyihtahk , ôma k-ôh-itwêt . “My brother will hear me,” was her idea in speaking so.
êkos âti-pônahk . Thereupon she went inside and put fuel on the fire.
nahapiw . She sat down.
êh-pa-pimisihk ôw oskinîkiw , waniskâw , êh-otinahk kicohcikanis mîna wîpisisah . The youth arose from where he lay, and took the flute and his arrows.
êkwah mâskosiyah otinam , iskotêw êh-akwâsiwêpahahk . Also he took some dried incense-grass and pushed back the fire.

êkotah astâw maskosiyah , êh-kaskâpahtêyik , kicohcikanis ôma êkotah êh-itisinahk , êh-miyâhkasahk . There he placed the grass, and when it began to make smoke, he held the little flute over it, perfuming the incense.

êkosi ômis îtwêw :
hê êy , nimisê , êh-kitimâkinâtân , êkâ kêkway k-ô-wih-nipahtâyân , osâm mistahi t-âtoskêyin , êy-itêyimitân , itêw omisah ; At the same time he spoke as follows: “Dear me, sister, it is because I feel sorry for you that I have not been killing anything, because I thought you would have too much work,” he told his sister; LB: A good instance of bravado: one lets a bad situation go far, and then, before acting, belittles the danger by giving a trivial reason for the delay.

seg.gloss: “Throw open the door-flap!”

p.seg: yôhtênam aw îskwêw , êkwah aw ôskinîkiw êh-kitohcikêt . The woman opened the doorway, and the youth played on his flute.
êh-kîsi-kitohtât , akotâw . When he had done playing music, he hung it up.

kiyipah kâ-pâpayiyit apisi-môsosah , êh-mihcêtiyit , êkotah iskwâhtêmihk ê-pimipayiyit , êwakoni êh-pâh-pimwât . At once there came running dwarf-moose in great number, and as they ran past the doorway, he kept shooting them.
iyikohk êh-mêstinahk wîpisisah , êkoyikohk pôyôw . He stopped only when he had used up his arrows.
êhci pikoh mihcêt mistahi nipahêw . He killed a great many of them.
êkoyikohk tapasiyiwah êyakoni . Then they ran away.

seg.gloss: “There, sister, go get my arrows.
If they are bloody, wipe them off.”

p.seg: tâpwê wayawîw aw îskwêw . Accordingly, the woman went outside.
êh-itâpit , mihcêt apisi-môsosah nipahêyiwa . When she looked to see, he had killed many dwarf-moose.
hây hây ! êkwah kê-mîcisot nisîmis ! itwêw , acosisah ôhi êh-wâh-wîhkwatinahk , êh-ati-kâsîhahk . “Splendid! Now my brother will eat!” she said, as she kept pulling out the arrows and wiping them.
êh-pîhtokatât , pôti kî-mosêskatêyiwa osîma , êh-wêwêkinamiyit otakohpiyihk . When she brought them indoors, there was her brother undresseed, wrapped up in his blanket-robe.

ê-kih-otinamiyit acosisah , ôh ôtayôwinisiyiwa ,
nimisê , wayawîwêpinayi ! When he had taken back his arrows, then, of his clothes, he said, “Sister, throw them out of the lodge!” CHECK wayawîwêpinayi
êh-wayawîwêpinahk , êkwah omôhkomân otinam , êh-wayawît . When she had thrown them out, she took her knife and went out.
êh-nanâtawâpahtahk ôhi kâ-wayawîwêpinahk , namoya wâpahtam . When she looked about to see the things she had thrown out, she did not see them.
êkosi êkwah êh-wiyanihtâkêt . Then she set about skinning and cutting up the game.
ôh apisi-môsosah ê-kîsi-wiyanihât , iyâyaw paminawasôw . When she had cleaned those dwarf-moose, she set eagerly about her cooking.
êh-kîsi-mîcisot , êkwah ôw âpisi-môsoswayâna nêô otinêw , ê-wîh-pâswât . When she had eaten, sbe took four of the skins of the dwarf-moose to dry.
êkos owiyâsima pîhtokêyâwatâw . Then she brought in her meat.
êkwah âtiht wayawîtimihk astêyiwa , sâm mihcêt kâh-nipahâyit . But some was left outside, for he had killed too many.

êh-kîsi-nahastât , êkwah pîhtokêw , pêskis mîna êh-paminawasot , âskaw êh-atoskâtât ôh âpisi-môsoswayâna . When she had arranged it all, she came in, and again attended to her cooking, even while working the hides of the dwarf-moose.
êh-otâkosiniyik , âsay kîsihêw , êkwah êh-kaskikwâtahk osîma êh-otayôwinisiyit . Towards evening, she had finished tanning them and began sewing clothes for her brother.
kêkâc ta-kawisimocik , êh-ispayiyik , kîsihtâw . When it was almost time for them to go to bed, she had finished them.
itisinamawêw osîma . She handed them to her brother.
postayôwinisêw aw oskinîkiw . The youth put on the clothes.
âsay mîna kotakah pâswêw . Then she dried some more.
êkosi ê-kawisimot awa oskinîkiw , awa wiy îskwêw atoskâtêw apisi-môswayâna . Then, when the youth went to bed, the woman kept on working the moose-hides.
piyis ê-nôhtêhkwasit , kawisimôw . At last, when she grew sleepy, she went to bed.
kîksêpâ êh-pêkopayit , âsay osîma simatapiyiwa . Early in the morning, when she awoke, her brother was already sitting up.
êkosi paminawasôw . Accordingly, she cooked.
ê-kîsi-mîcisocik , âsay mîna aw oskinîkiw iskotêw otinam , mîna êh-miyâhkasahk okitohcikanis . When they had eaten, the youth again took some fire and burned incense to his little flute.
yôhtêwêpinah , nimisê ! itêw . “Open the door-flap, sister!” he said to her.
ê-ki-yôhtênahk , kitohtâw . When she had opened it, he blew on his flute.
êkwah wâwâskêsiwah êyakô pêcimêw , êyakonih êkwah êh-nôcihât . This time he brought deer to his call, and gave chase to them.
iyikohk mîna êh-mêstinahk wîpisisah , êkoyikohk mîna tapasiyiwa . Again, only when he had used up his arrows, did they flee.

seg.gloss: “There, sister, take up my arrows!”

p.seg: êh-wayawît aw îskwêw , â , mihcât êkwah wawâskêsiw . When the woman went out, there were many deer.
hây hây ! mahtiy êkwa êk êh-nôhtêhkatêyân ! itwêw aw îskwêw , ôhi êh-wâh-wîhkwatinahk acosisah . “Splendid! Now, surely, I shall not go hungry!” she said, as she went about pulling free the arrows.
êh-pîhtokatât , âsay mîna kîh-mosêskatêpiyiwa osîma . When she brought them in, again her brother sat without his clothes.
hâ , nimisê , êyakonih anih wayawîwêpinah ! itêw . “There, sister, throw these things out!” he said to her.
wayawîwêpinam . She threw them out.
êkwah omôhkomân otinam aw îskwêw , ê-wîh-wiyanihtâkêt . Then she took her knife, to clean the game.
nama kêkway wâpahtam osîma otayôwinisiyiwa , ayis êh-wêpinamiyit . Not a thing did she see of her brother's clothes; he had cast them off.
êkosi êkwah mîna wiyinihtâkêw . Then, accordingly, she again cleaned game.
êh-kîsi-wiyinihtâkêt , êkoyikohk êkwah kîsitêpôw , ê-wîh-mîcisocik . When she had finished cleaning game, she cooked, that they might eat.
piyisk mîcisôwak . Then they ate.
ê-kîsi-mîcisot , iyâyaw êkwah osîhêw pisi-môswayânah , êkwah pêyak wâwaskêsiwa , wawâskêsiwayâna . When she had eaten, she eagerly went about preparing dwarf-moose skins and one deer-skin.
iyikohk êy-otâkosik , kahkiyaw kîsihtâw , êkwah pitah êh-paminawasot . By evening she had finished it all, and then she stopped to cook.
êh-kîsi-mîcisocik , êkwah kaskikwâsôw . When they had eaten, she sewed.
êkwah kîsihtâw otayôwinisiyiwa osîma . Then she finished her brother's clothes.
iyâyaw êkwah pâsam pahkêkinwah . Then, with zeal she went about drying hides.
piyis mistahi tipiskâyiki , êyikohk kawisimôw . At last, when it was quite dark, she went to bed.
iyikohk êh-pêkopayit , êkoyikohk sâsay waniskâyiwa osîma . When she awoke, her brother had already got up.
kakwêyâhôw êh-paminawasot . She worked quickly, cooking the meal.
mayaw êh-kîsi-mîcisocik , âsay mîna miyâhkasamiyiwa okicohcikanisiyiw . When they had eaten, he again burned incense under his flute.

seg.gloss: “Open the door!”

p.seg: ê-yôhtêwêpinahk , kitohtâw . When she had opened it, he played.
âsay mîna pêcimêw môswah , êkwah êyakonih mîna êh-nôcihât . As before, he made moose come by the sound, for these he now sought.
iyikohk mîna êh-mêstinahk wîpisisah , pôyôw . Again, when he had exhausted his arrows, he ceased.

seg.gloss: “Now, sister, go take up my arrows!”

p.seg: êh-wayawît , mihcêt êkwah môswah . When she went out, there were many moose.

hây hây hây ! êkwah êkâ mayaw kê-nôhtêhkatêyâhk ! itwêw aw îskwêw , êh-ât-otinahk acosisah . “Splendid, splendid! Now we shall not for a long time go hungry!” said the woman, as she set about taking the arrows.
êh-pîhtokêt , âsay mîna mosêskatêpiyiwa . When she went indoors, again he sat undressed.
â , nimisê , êkonih anih wayawîwêpinah ! itêw omisah . “Now, sister, throw those things out!” he told his sister.
wayawîwêpinam ; êkoyikohk omôhkomân êh-otinahk , êh-wayawît , ê-wâh-wiyanihtâkêt . She threw them outside; then she took her knife and went out and began to clean the carcasses.
êkwah wiyanihtâkêw . She skinned them and cut them up.
ê-kîsiyinihtâkêt , êkoyikohk êkwah paminawasôw . When she had finished cleaning them she set about her cooking.

ê-kîsi-mîcisocik , êkwa mîna êh-osîhât apisi-mososwayâna , pêyak mînah wâwâskêsiwêkin ,
cit-ôtakohpit , êy-itêyihtah , kêkâc êh-ati-tipiskâyik , kîsihtâw , pita min êkwah êh-paminawasot , ê-wîh-asamât osîma . When they had eaten, then she again prepared skins of dwarf-moose, and a deer-hide, with the thought, “that he may have it for a blanket-robe,” and just as darkness was coming on, she had them dome, and stopped to cook again, to feed her brother.
tâpwê ê-kîsi-mîcisocik , êkwah kaskikwâsôw , ayôwinisah êw-osîhtât . So, when they had eaten, she sewed and made clothes.

maywês kawisimoyit osîma , âsay kîsihtâw , êkwah kotakah êh-pâswât apisi-môswayânah êkwah môswayânah . Before her brother went to bed she had them done, and already was drying other skins of dwarf-moose and of moose.
iyikohk iskoh ê-nôhtêhkwasit , pôn-âtoskêw , ê-wîh-nipât . When she got sleepy, she ceased work and went to bed.
êh-wâpahk , ê-waniskât , âsay kî-simatapiyiwa osîma . The next morning, when she arose, her brother was already sitting up.
êkosi êkwah ati-paminawasôw , ê-wîh-mîcisocik . So then she cooked, that they might eat.
mayaw ê-kîsi-mîcisocik , mîna miyâhkasamiyiwa kitohcikanis . As soon as they had eaten, he again burned incense to his flute.
yôhtêwêpinam aw îskwêw , ê-kitohtâyit osîma . The woman threw open the door-flap, and her brother played the flute.
êkwah mostoswah pâpayiyiwa , êkonih mîna êh-nôcihât . Then buffalo came running, and he made a killing of these too.
êyikoh mîna êh-mêstinahk wîpisisah , êkoyikohk pôni-nipahêw . Again, only when he had used up his arrows did he cease killing them.
êkosi , nimisê ! otinah nîpisisah ! itêw . “So there, sister! Take up my arrows!” he told her.
êh-wayawît aw îskwêw , âsay mîna miywêyihtam . When the woman went out, again she was glad.

hây hây ! êkos êcik ôma êkâ wîhkâc kê-kôta-mîciyân ! itwêw aw îskwêw , êy-âh-otinahk acosisah . “Splendid! So now, it appears, I shall never be at a loss for something to eat!” she said, as she went on taking the arrows.
êh-pîhtokêt , âsay mîna kî-mosêskatêpiyiwa osîma . When she went in, again her brother sat without his clothes.

â , nimisê , êyakonih wayawîwêpinah ! itik ;
êh-manâh-mistahâtoskahitân , êkâ k-ôh-ma-mâciyân , itêw . “Now, sister, throw these out of the lodge!” he told her; “It was because I hesitated to give you too much work, that I never used to hunt,” he told her.
êkosi wayawîwêpinam aw îskwêw , êh-otinahk omôhkomân , ê-wayawît , êh-wiyanihtâkêt . So the woman threw them out of the lodge, and took her knife, and went out and cleaned the game.
iyâyaw iyâpêsisah wiyanihêw . She eagerly set about skinning a young bull-calf.
êyakonih êkwah t-ôtakohpiw nisîm , itêyihtam . “Now my brother shall have a blanket-robe of this one,” she thought.
ê-kîsi-wiyanihât , pit êwakoni pîhtokahêw , itah ta-pâsôyit êh-kikamohât . When she had skinned it, she first brought it inside and fastened it to dry.
êkoyikohk êkwah ê-ntawi-wiyanihtâkêt . Then she went again to cut up game.
êh-ay-âpihtâ-kîsikâyik , pit êkwah paminawasôw , ê-wih-asamât osîma . When noon came, she stopped to cook a meal, to give her brother to eat.

ê-kîsi-mîcisot , êkwa mîna osîhêw pisi-môsoswayânah , êh-kîsihât , êkwa mîn ôhi mostoswayânah . When she had eaten, again she prepared skins of dwarf-moose, and tanned them, and also that buffalo-robe.
êh-otâkosik , kîsihêw . By evening she had tanned it.
pit êkwah mîna paminawasôw , êh-mîcisocik . Then she stopped, to cook, and they ate.

ê-kîsi-mîcisocik , êkwah mîna êh-kaskikwâsot , mistahîs êh-tipiskâyik , kîsihtâw ayôwinisah , êkwa mîn âwa oskinîkiw êh-postayôwinisêt , awa wiy iskwêw êh-ay-atoskâtahk owiyâsima . When they had eaten, and again she sewed, then, when it was quite dark, she finished the garments, and the youth put them on, while the woman went on preparing the stores of meat.
êyikohk mistah êh-tipiskâyik , kawisimôw . When it was entirely dark, she went to bed.

êyikohk êh-pêkopayit , kêyâpic nipâyiwa osîma , iyâyaw ê-paminawasot , ê-wîh-asamât osîma . When she awoke, her brother was still asleep, and eagerly she set about cooking, that she might give her brother to eat.
êyikohk ê-kîsi-paminawasot , waniskâyiwa osîma , êkwah êh-mîcisocik . When she had finished cooking, her brother arose, and they ate.
ê-kîsi-mîcisocik , namoya êkwah miyâhkasamiyiwa . When they had eaten, this time he did not burn incense.
êkwah wiya wayawîw , êy-osîhtât itah ê-wîh-akotât owiyâsima , têsipicikan . She went out and set up a drying-frame, on which to hang her meats.

êkosi êkwah ê-sâkaskinahtât êwako têsipicikan , kotakah mîna osîhtâw têsipicikana , êkotah t-âstât owiyâsima . Then, when she had filled that drying-frame, she set up other drying-frames, on which to place her stores of meat.
piyisk kinwêsk atoskâtam , ê-nahastât wiyâsah . She worked a long time at placing the meat.

iyikohk êh-kîsihtât , êkwah osîhtâw pahkêkinwa , ayôwinisa êkwah ê-wiw-osîhtowât osîma , tâpwê êh-kîsihtât , êh-pâh-pîmikitahk . When she had done, she prepared hides, intending to make clothes for her brother, and she finished them and ornamented them with quill-work.

kinwêsk êkwah êh-ayâcik , ômis îtwêw aw oskinîkiw :
hâw , nimisê , kiyânaw cî pikoh ôma k-êsinâkosiyahk ? itêw . When they had stayed there a long time, the youth spoke as follows: “Now, sister, is it only we who look like this?” he asked her.

seg.q: ê ê ê , nisîmis , mihcêtiwak ôma ayîsiyiniwak , tâpiskôc kiya êkwah niya êkotôwahk êy-ihtâcik ;
seg.gloss: “Dear me, little brother, in truth there are many people who exist in the same form as you and I;

seg.q: mâka namoya kwayask êy-itâtisicik , êh-mâh-mawinêhotocik , siyâkôcihitotwâwi , êh-nipahitocik .
seg.gloss: but they are not of decent character; they always challenge each other to contend, and when they have defeated each other, they kill each other.

seg.q:
êywako êh-pakwâtamân , kâ-kîh-pê-sipwêhtahitân , êh-apisîsisiyan ,
mâskôc wîh-ôhpikicih ,
ê-kîh-itêyimitân .
seg.gloss: It was because I hated this, that I took you away and brought you here when you were small, thinking of you, ‘Perhaps he will grow up.’

p.seg: ôtê isi âpihtâ-kîsikâk isi mihcêtiwak ayîsiyiniwak , mâka ê-maci-nôcihtâcik , itêw ; Here, in the direction of noon are many people, but they are of evil purposes,” she told him;

seg.q: iskwêwak wacistwanihk êh-akosîcik , awiyak oskinîkiw êkotê têkohtêci , âsay ê-sîhkimiht ta-kîhcêkosît , otihtâci awiyak ta-wîkimât .
seg.gloss: “Women are poised aloft in a nest, and whenever any youth arrives there, he is urged to climb up, being told that if anyone reaches them, he may marry them.
But before they reach the goal, the youths fall down, falling to their death.
Then those people eat them.
This is no good thing.

seg.q: êkwah ôtê mâmihk , êkotê misâw ôtênaw ;
seg.gloss: And here, in the east, yonder is a great town;

seg.q: êwakonik êh-kâ-kakwê-nakatitocik , awiyak nêkatihcih , ê-misi-wanâcihiht , mîn êyakonik êh-môtocik .
seg.gloss: the people there run races, and when anyone is outrun, he is destroyed, for these people, too, eat each other.
That is why, ‘Would that I might bring him up!’ was my thought concerning you.

p.seg: âyiman nânitaw ta-kîh-itohtêyin , itêw osîma . It will be no light thing for you to go anywhere,” she told her brother.
hâ , nimisê , wâpahkih nka-sipwêhtân , itêw . “Now then, sister, tomorrow I shall go forth,” he told her.

mâtôw aw îskwêw , êh-pakwâtahk ê-wî-sipwêhtêyit osîma ,
mâskôc ta-misi-wanâcihâw , êh-itêyihtahk . The woman wept, for she hated her brother's going forth, thinking, “Perhaps he will be destroyed.”
êkosi êkway ê-tipiskâk , kawisimôw . So, when night came, she went to bed.
kîksêpâ waniskâw aw îskwêw , ê-wi-sipwêhtêyit osîma , êh-kîsitêpot . Early she arose to cook for her brother's departure.

êh-kîsi-mîcisot , wawêyîw aw oskinîkiw , ê-pasikôt , okitohcikanis ôma êh-tâpiskahk , ôtêh êh-astât ospiskwanihk kicohcikanis . When that youth had eaten, he made himself ready and rose to his feet, hanging his little flute round his neck, placing it to hang on his back.

â , nimisê , awiyak wâh-wîhicih , ‘opipikwan kâ-nayahtahk ’ nik-êsiyîhkâson , itwêw aw oskinîkiw , êh-ati-wayawît , ê-sipwêhtêt . “Now then, sister, whenever anyone is to name me, ‘Flute-Bearer’ I shall be called,” said the youth, as he stepped out of the lodge and went forth.

âpihtâ-kîsikâhk isi sipwêhtêw , êkotê wacistwanihk k-âkosiyit iskwêwah , êkonih êh-ntawâpamât . He set out in the direction of noon, toward where the women were poised aloft in the nest, for them he was going to see.
nîswâw êh-nipât , êkoyikohk otihtam ôtênaw . When he had slept twice, he reached the town.

êh-takohtêt ,
êwahô-ô-ô , opipikwan kâ-nayahtahk takosin ! itwêwân . When he arrived, “Yohoho, Flute-Bearer has come!” was said of him.
hâ , pêyakwayak ntomâw . Then he was called to one lodge.

mistahi miywêyihtamwak ôk âyîsiyiniwak ,
êkwah kê-mîcisoyâhk ! êh-itêyihtahkik . Those people rejoiced in the thought, “Now we shall eat!”

êkotah ayâw wîsahkêcâhk , ôh ôkimâwa êh-oy-ôhtâwîhkât , ôh ôskinîkiskwêwa êh-osîmit . In that place dwelt Wisahketchahk, having adopted the chief as his father and those women as his sisters. LB ad {êkotah ayâw wîsahkêcâhk,} In the succeeding episode Wisahketchahk seems to play merely the role of one of the spirit-animals. At the end of the story he is more in character. The same is true of a version obtained on Star-Blanket Reserve. CHECK êh-oy-ôhtâwîhkât
tâpwê êh-tipiskâyik , itohtêw wîsahkêcâhk . And so, at night, Wisahketchahk came there.
êh-pîhtokêt , apiyiwah ôhi oskinîkiwa . When he entered the lodge, there sat the youth.
opipikwan kâ-nayahtahk , mâna kipê-wîwih nisîmak , itêw . “Flute-Bearer, it would seem that you have come to take my younger sisters to wife,” he said to him.
namoya ! itik . “No!” the other answered him.

seg.gloss: “Oh yes! Tomorrow you will come to take my sisters to wife.

p.seg: otihtatwâwi , kika-wîwin , wacistwanihk êh-akosîcik nisîmak , itêw . If you reach them, you shall have them to wife, my sisters who are poised aloft in the nest,” he told him.
âhag , itik . “Oh, very well,” the other answered him.
tâpwê kîwêw wîsahkêcâhk . So Wisahketchahk went home.
âh , nôhtâh , êh-pê-wîwit ês âni opipikwan kâ-nayahtahk , itêw . “Why, father, it seems that Flute-Bearer has come to take wives,” he said to him.
êahag ! itwêyiwa . “Oh, yes!” said the other.
piyis wâpaniyiw . The next day came.
wayawîw kîkisêpâ , êh-kîsi-mâh-mîcisôwiht awa wîsahkêcâhk . In the morning, when his people had eaten, Wisahketchahk went out of the lodge.

seg.gloss: “Now, now, ye men, come forth, come forth!

p.seg: opipikwan kâ-nayahtahk pê-kitâpamik , ê-wîh-nitawi-wîwit ! itwêw , êh-ati-sipwêhtêt . Come look at Flute-Bearer, who is going to take wives!” he cried, as he went out.
â , kahkiyaw ayîsiyiniwak tohtêwak , êkwah ê-wîhkwêpicik tâwâyihk êkotah êh-cimasot awa mistik . Then all the people came and sat in a circle round where that tree stood upright in the ground.
êh-kîsi-apicik , kâ-pê-takohtêt opipikwan kâ-nayahtahk . When they had seated themselves, there came Flute-Bearer.
êh-kitâpamât , capasis ayâyiwa wacistwanihk , êh-takohtêt , sêmâk êh-ati-mâcikiyit . When he looked at them, they were quite low with their nest, but as he came nearer, at once they began to rise.
êkosi ê-wîh-otihtât wacistonihk , pa-pakamahwêyiwa mistikwah ; kâwi kinwâskosiyiwa . And when he was about to reach them in their nest, they would beat the tree; it would grow longer again.
êkwah êkota wîpisisah âpacihtâw , êh-ohci-kîhcêkosît . Then he used his arrows, climbing by their means.
miyêstinahkih , êh-pa-pakamahwât opîhtatwânah , kâwi sâkaskinêyiwa wîpisisah . Whenever he had used them up, he would beat his quiver, and it would be full of arrows.

êkosi tahkih ê-sipwêyâhtawit , wiy âwa wîsahkêcâhk tahk êh-itâpit ,
asawâpamihk , ta-pêtakocihk opipkwan kâ-nayahtahk ! êh-itwêt wîsahkêcâhk . Then, as he went climbing on and on, and Wisahketchahk was always looking up, the latter cried, “Watch for him, all of you, for Flute-Bearer to come tumbling!”
piyisk nêwâw ê-yahkîmoyit ôhi mistikwah , namoya êkwah wâpahtam askiy . At last, when four times the tree had lengthened, he no longer saw the earth.
hâw , otinam omistanipiwayân , êh-pôtâtahk . Then he took a wisp of fur and blew on it.
otêh tahkohc wacistwanihk nika-pônâsin , ôk îskwêwak itah k-âpicik ! itwêw . “There to the nest let me be blown, there where those women are!” he said.
tâpwê êkotê pônâsiw . Truly, he was blown to that place.
êkosi mâka kê-wîkimitâhk ! itik iskwêwah . “And so now you will marry us!” said the women to him.

seg.gloss: “Indeed, yes!”

p.seg: otinêw ôh ôsimimâwa , êh-nîhciwêpinât . He took hold of the younger one and threw her down.
itah êh-s-ôhciskawapit wîsahkêcâhk , êkotah pahkisiniyiwa . Right in front of Wisahketchahk, as he sat, she fell to the ground.
awîn ôh , ôsîma ! Why, it was one of his sisters!
mitoni wanâcipayiyiwa . [no translation]
wass ! itwêw wîsahkêcâhk . “Fie!” cried Wisahketchahk.
kotakah mîn ôhi nîhciwêpinêw . He threw down the other one as well.

piyêtisâpamâcih wîsahkêcâhk , âsay êh-sâkôwêt ,
êkwah piyêtakocihk opipikwan kâ-nayahtahk ! êh-itwêt , mâka piyâkisiniyici , namoya kwayask isi-wâpamêw osîma . When Wisahketchahk saw her coming, again he whooped and cried, “Here comes Flute-Bearer, tumbling!” but when she hit the ground, in no seemly way, he saw his sister. CHECK piyâkisiniyici
nêpêwisiw . He was ashamed.
êkwah awa opipikwan kâ-nayahtahk pôtâtam oma mistanipiwayân . Then Flute-Bearer breathed upon the hair of fur.
wâhyaw ôtê nka-nîhtâsin ! itwêw . “Far yonder let me be blown to earth!” he said.

êkosi wîsahkêcâhk ômis îtwêw :
hê hah ! tâpwê nikakwayakihik , nisîma kit-êsi-nêpêwisiyân k-êsiwêpinât ! itêw ; Then Wisahketchahk said, “Heavens! Truly, he has given me a shock, throwing my sisters in a way to cause me shame!” he said of him;

seg.gloss: “Whereto in all the extent of the earth will you flee?
I shall go out to kill you, Flute-Bearer! You have put me to shame!”

p.seg: êkosi êkwah êh-ntonikêt , êh-wâh-wâskâpahtât , ômis îsi , tântêh ta-nîhtakosiyit êh-ntonahk . Then he made search, running round about, like this, looking for where the other should come to earth.
kîtahtawê miskam itah êsah êy-ôh-tapasiyit . Presently he found the place from which the other apparently had started to flee.
êkwah mitihtêw . Then he tracked him.

namoya ka-kîh-wanihitin , niya ka-kih-osîhtâyân askiy ! itêw , êh-micihcipâyîstawât . “Not by any chance shall I lose track of you, I who created the earth!” he called to him, as he pursued the trace of him.
kîtahtawê wîh-atimik . Then, in time, he was about to overtake him.

êkwah êh-pêtwêwitamiyit wîsahkêcâhkwah ,
hâw , ôtah ta-wîh-kâyâs-âyiwiw acosis ! itwêw awa opipikwan kâ-nayahtahk , êh-kê-kêtaskisinêt ,
â , nimaskisinitik , tapasîk ! êh-itwêt . Then, when Wisahketchahk came noisily near, “Now, let there be an old arrow here!” said Flute-Bearer, taking off his moccasins, and saying, “Now, my moccasins, flee!”
yahô ! itwêw wîsahkêcâhk , êh-wâpahtahk ôm âcosis ; “Yoho!” cried Wisahketchahk, when he saw that arrow;
â , kiy ôma opipikwan kâ-nayahtahk ! itam acosis , êh-wâ-wâpahtahk ; “Ho, it is you, Flute-Bearer!” he said to the arrow, as he examined it;

seg.gloss: “Yah, but there go his tracks yon way!

p.seg: âh , kayâs nimosômipanak ôtah kâ-kîh-nôtinitocik , êkospîh ômah ê-kîh-patahotocik om âcosis ! itwêw . No, when my grandfathers fought here of yore, they must have missed a shot with this arrow!” he said.
êkos îsi êh-îkatawêpinahk , êkwah mîna êh-nawaswêt . So he threw it aside, and went on with his chase.
mayaw êh-âkawêwêt , kont îtê isi tapasîw êkwah awa opipikwan kâ-nayahtahk . As soon as he was over the hill, Flute-Bearer ran off in some other direction.
wîsahkêcâhk iyikohk itêh êh-pônihtiniyikih maskisinah , pê-kîwêw . Wisahketchahk, as soon as he had got to where those moccasins had come to rest, turned about and came back.
yôh ! ayôkw êcik âna opipikwan kâ-nayahtahk k-ayîsîhot ! itwêw ; “Oho! So this was the way Flute-Bearer disguised himself!” he cried;
namoya êkwah kika-wanîhin ! itêw . “You shall not again get away from me!” he told him.
êh-takopahtât , awênipan acosis , êsa kâh-tapasiyit ! When he got there on the run, there was no trace of the arrow, it was plain that he had fled!
wînikonêmahkay ! itwêw wîsahkêcâhk , âsay mîna êh-nawaswât . “Filthy scab!” cried Wisahketchahk, and again gave chase.

kîtahtawê mîna êkwah ê-wîh-atimât , kêkâc êkwah t-âtimâpamât , êkoyikohk êh-askôwât , ômis îtwêw aw ôpipikwan kâ-nayahtahk :
hâw , nik-êskwêwin ! nka-pwâwîn ! Presently, when again he was about to overtake him, and was close upon his heels, Flute-Bearer said, “Now, let me be a woman! [no translation]”
tâpwê êkos îsinâkosiw . Truly he took that form.
ê-sâkêwêt , awîn ôhi , iskwêwah ka-papâmohtêyit . When he came over the hill, there was a woman walking about.

seg.gloss: “This time you shall not deceive me!
It is you, Flute-Bearer!
Now I shall club you!”

p.seg: mâtôw aw îskwêw . That woman wept.

seg.q: mîn êcik an êwako êkâ kê-kitimâkinawit !
seg.gloss: “So it seems that this one, too, will not take pity on me!

seg.q:
ôtah kâ-pimpahtât ,
êkâya nakasin ! ahpôh ka-wîkimitin ! êh-ât-îtak , êkâ kâ-tâpwêhtawit !
seg.gloss: That one who ran by here, even though I said to him, ‘Do not leave me! I will marry you, if you like!’ yet he gave me no heed!

p.seg: kayâs êh-ntawi-mônahikêhk ê-kîh-wanisiniyân , itwêw aw îskwêw ; A long time ago, when we went to dig tubers, I got lost,” said the woman;

êkos êh-ât-îtak , ‘hâw , osâm wîsahkêcâhk ninawaswâtik , ê-wîh-nipahit !’ nitik , itwêyiwa . “Even though I said this to him, he said to me, ‘No, Wisahketchahk is too hot in pursuit of me, to kill me!’” Thus spoke the woman.
â , namoya ! namoya kika-wayêsimin ! kiy ôma , opipikwan kâ-nayahtahk ! itêw . “Oh, no! You shall not deceive me! This is you, Flute-Bearer!” he told him.

seg.gloss: “Do take pity on me!
Do not leave!

p.seg: ahpôh ka-wîkimitn ! itêw wîsahkêcâhkwa . If you like, I will marry you!” he said to Wisahketchahk.
mahti mâka nîpaw ôtahk ! itêw wîsahkêcâhk . [no translation]
êkwah ômisi tôtam , ê-wîh-tâhkinât . [no translation]
kah ! tâpwê ês âni kiya iskwêw ! itêw ; [no translation] he said to him;

seg.gloss: “Wait here for me;
I am going off to kill Flute-Bearer;
the fact is, he has greatly shamed me by throwing down my sisters.

p.seg: êkâya nântaw itohtê ! itêw . Do not go off anywhere!” he told him.
êhag ! kiyipah mâka takohtêhkan , itik . “Very well! But come soon,” he answered him.

seg.gloss: “Yes, [sic]

p.seg: êkotah pêhin , niwîkimâkan ! itêw . wait here for me, my wife!” he said to him.
êkosi ê-sipwêpahtât , mayaw êh-âkawêwêt , tapasiyiwa . Then, when he ran off, as soon as he was round a bend, the other fled.
mâka mîna wâhyaw êh-ayât , omaskisiniyiwah piko kiy-astêyiwa . Again, when he had gone a long ways, there lay only the other's moccasins.

seg.q: êhêhê ! êkota mâna kah-kisiwâyit opipikwan kâ-nayahtahk !
seg.gloss: “Dear me! This is the way Flute-Bearer always gets me angry!
You shall not deceive me this time!

seg.q: itah êkwah kê-wâpamitân , êkwah ka-pakamahotin ! ka-nipahitn !
seg.gloss: Wherever I see you, I will strike you down! I will kill you!

p.seg: kikisiwi-nêpêwihin , nisîmak êkâ kwayask êh-isiwêpinamawiyin ! itêw . You made me furious with shame, when you threw my sisters down to me in unseemly wise!” he cried to him.
êh-takopahtât , awînipan ôh îskwêwah , êsa kâh-tapasiyit . When he came there on the run, where was that woman! Plainly, the other had fled.

seg.q: hâ hah ! êkotah mâna kâh-kisiwâhit opipikwan kâ-nayahtahk !
seg.gloss: “Hoho! This is the way Flute-Bearer always gets me angry!
This time you shall not escape me!
seg.q: êkoyikohk mistahi êh-pimipahtâyân , osâm êh-kisiwi-cîsihiyin , iskwêw êh-itêyimitân !
seg.gloss: Now I have done enough running, and letting you fool me to the uttermost rage, thinking you a woman!”

p.seg: kîtahtawê êh-pa-pimipahtât , âsay mîna kisiwâk askôk . Presently, as he ran on and on, again he was close upon his heels.
hâw ! itwêw , mistikwah êh-otinahk , tâpiskôc wâskahikan êh-itastât ; “Now!” he said, taking up some sticks and laying them in the shape of a wooden house;
hâw , ta-kayâs-âyiwiw wâskahikan ! itwêw . “Now, let there be an old wooden house!” he said.
nîso mîna mistikwah otinêw , êh-pôh-pôtâtât . Then he took two saplings and breathed upon each.

seg.gloss: “Now, you, you are to be women, half-breed women!
And I shall be an old man, and half-breed!

p.seg: mitoni nka-kawikihkân ! itwêw . I shall be very old!” he said.
tâpwê kisêyiniwiw . Truly he turned into an old man.
pîhcâyihk ayâwak . They were inside the house.
kîtahtawê wîsahkêcâhk ka-sâkêwêpahtât . Presently Wisahketchahk came running over the hill.
wâpahtam wâskahikanis . He saw a little wooden house.

seg.gloss: “Ha, I shall club you all the more surely!

p.seg: kiy ôma , opipikwan kâ-nayahtahk , k-êsihoyin ! itêw . This is but your disguise, Flute-Bearer!” he called to him.
êh-at-takopahtât , kâ-pê-wayawiyit oskinîkiskwêwa . When he came a-running, out from the house came the young women.

seg.gloss: “You have angered me by putting me to shame!

p.seg: sôskwâc êkwah kika-nipahitn , opipikwan kâ-nayahtahk ! itêw . Now I shall kill you at once, Flute-Bearer!” he said to them.

seg.q: nâ , mîn êcik ân êyakô êkâ kê-tâpwêhtâkoyâhk !
seg.gloss: “Gracious, and so this one, too, will pay no heed to us!

seg.q: awiyak otihtikoyahko , wîkimâhkêk , ê-kîh-itikoyâhk nôhtâwînân , osâm êh-kisêyiniwit , êkâ êh-kîh-pamihikoyâhk , êh-ât-âyâkoyâhk .
seg.gloss: ‘If anyone comes to where we are, do you marry him,’ our father told us, for he is so very old, he cannot care for us, though he is with us.

seg.q: osâm wîsahkêcâhk nnawaswâtik , ê-wîh-nipahit , k-êtwêt aw ôtah kâ-pimâmot , kiya kêkoc kitimâkihtawinân !
seg.gloss: One man who ran by here said, ‘Wisahketchahk is too hot on my trail; he wants to kill me.’ So do you at least hear us with pity.

p.seg: ahpoh ê-isi-nîsiyâhk ka-wîkimitnân ! itik . If you like, the two of us will marry you!” they told him.

seg.gloss: “Really, I do fancy taking half-breed women for wives!
And I am very tired.
Suppose I do stop here till tomorrow.
Tomorrow I shall go kill him.

p.seg: kîh-nipahakih , êkoyikohk ka-pê-pamihitinâwâw , itêw . When I have killed him, then I shall come here and provide for you,” he told them.
pîhtokê mâka ! itik . “But do come in!” they said to him.
êh-pîhtokêt , awîn ôhi , kisêyiniwânêsah kîh-apiyiwa . When he went in, who was that! An old man was sitting there.

seg.gloss: “Dear me, your father is really to be pitied!”
“Yes, indeed.”

p.seg: ka-pamihitnâwâwan , k-êsi-nitawêyihtahk kôhtâwiyiwâw , itêw . “I shall take care of you both for him, in whatever way your father desires,” he told them. CHECK TA relational?
âh , apiw nipêwinihk , tahk êh-mâsihikot , âyîtaw ohci êh-apiyit . [no translation]

piyis ê-tipiskâyik ,
nnêstosin , nîwitik . pita nipâtân , itêw . [no translation] [Finally, when it was night, he said, “I am tired, wife. Let's sleep.”]
êkwah kawisimôwak . [no translation]

pêyak wêhtiskawisinôstawâci , kwêskipitik ôhi pêyak ,
pê-kwêskisinih ! êh-itikot . [no translation]
piyisk kapê-tipisk êkos êh-tôtâkot , nama kîh-nipâw . [no translation]
iyikohk kêkâc êh-wâpaniyik , êkoyikohk mitoni nêstohkwasiw . [no translation]
mayaw kâ-nipât , tapasiyiwa ôhi kisêyiniwânêsah . [no translation]

ômis îtêw kâhkâkiwah aw ôpipikwan kâ-nayahtahk :
ôtah mîtosihk akosî ! Thus spoke Flute-Bearer to a raven: “Perch here on the poplar! [sic] punctuation

seg.gloss: ‘Get up, Wisahketchahk!’ do you say to him;
‘Don't forget you were giving chase!’ do you say to him;

seg.q: mâk ân êkwa nikisiw-itisahok ! kitik , itâhkan ;
seg.gloss: ‘“But now he has got me angry, chasing me!” he says to you,’ do you say to him:

seg.q:
itah atimicih ,
êkwah nka-nipahâw ! kitik , itâhkan .
seg.gloss: ‘“Wherever he overtakes me, there I shall kill him!” he says to you,’ do you say to him.”

p.seg: êkos îs êh-sipwêhtêt . With that he made off.
ta-wih-nama-kêkwayiw ôma wâskahikanis ! itwêw , êkos êkos êh-sipwêhtêt . “Let this little wooden house disappear!” he said, and off he went.
kîtahtawê kâ-kâh-kitot kâhkâkiw . Presently there the raven gave its call.
pêkomik wîsahkêcâhk . It awakened Wisahketchahk.
êh-tôhkâpit , awîn ôma , wayawîtimihk kîh-nipâw ! When he opened his eyes, what was this? He had been sleeping out of doors!

âyîtaw ôtah mistikwah kîh-pimisiniyiwa ; êwakoni
iskwêw
kâ-kîh-itêyimât . At either side of him lay a stick of wood; it was these he had taken for women. interesting gender mismatch

wînikonêmahkay tân-tahtwâw êkwah ka-wayêsihit
itêw wîsahkêcâhk . “Filthy brute! How many times has he cheated me!” Wisahketchahk said of him.

êh-kitoyit kâhkâkiwa ,
â , wîsahkêcâhk ! Then the raven called: “Ho, Wisahketchahk!

seg.q: nikisiwâhik êkwah ! kitik aw ôpipikwan kâ-nayahtahk ;
seg.gloss: `He has got me angry now!' says Flute-Bearer to you;

p.seg: itah êkwah atimicih , nika-nipahâw êkwah ! kitik anih opipikwan kâ-nayahtahk , itik . `Wherever he overtakes me now, I shall kill him!' is what Flute-Bearer says to you,” it told him.
ta-wîh-ta-tâpwêw ôyâ ! itwêw wîsahkêcâhk ; “The fellow might be telling the truth!” said Wisahketchahk;

seg.gloss: “The fact is, he has fooled me three times now.

p.seg: namoya wîhkâc êkoyikohk awiyak niwayêsimik ! itwêw ; Never has anyone fooled me as much as that!” he said;
hâ , nika-pônihâ ! nika-kîwân , itwêw ; “Well, I will leave him alone! I will go home,” he said;
êkos âni ê-pimâtisiyin , opipikwan kâ-nayahtahk ! twêw wîsahkêcâhk . “So now you have got away with your life, Flute-Bearer!” said Wisahketchahk.
êkoyikohk êh-iskwâk âtayôhkêwin . That is the end of the sacred story.
